Article.ArticleTitle: Bifunctional investigation of ultra-small SnO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticle decorated rGO for ozone sensing and supercapacitor applications.

AbstractText: Ultrasmall SnO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles with an average size of 7 nm were synthesized by a hydrothermal method and composited with reduced graphene oxide (rGO) through an ultrasonic assisted solution process. The structural, functional, morphological and compositional properties of synthesised SnO<sub>2</sub> and rGO/SnO<sub>2</sub> were studied by XRD, FTIR, HRSEM, HRTEM, XPS and Raman analyses. The prepared materials were developed as a film over a PVA/KOH conductive layer coated substrate with varying thickness of 3, 5 and 7 μm to study their ozone sensing characteristics at room temperature. The physico-chemical properties reveal that the fabricated SnO<sub>2</sub> and rGO/SnO<sub>2</sub> nanocomposite films have a strong interaction with the ozone gas. Among the fabricated composite films rGO/SnO<sub>2</sub>-S1 film exhibits high ozone sensing response (38%) at room temperature. Additionally, the electrochemical performance of SnO<sub>2</sub> and rGO/SnO<sub>2</sub> nanocomposites was analysed and the rGO/SnO<sub>2</sub> nanocomposite exhibited higher specific capacitance (545 F g<sup>-1</sup>) than that of pure SnO<sub>2</sub> (236 F g<sup>-1</sup>) at a current density of 1 A g<sup>-1</sup> with higher cyclic stability (96%) than that of pure SnO<sub>2</sub> (86%) at the current density of 20 A g<sup>-1</sup> for a continuous 5000 charge-discharge cycles. Thus, the rGO/SnO<sub>2</sub> nanocomposite showed an excellent ozone sensing and energy storage performance.
